subject: Cybersecurity
title: Brute Force Attacks: Trying Every Combination
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Brute Force Attacks: Trying Every Combination.

hook.text: A computer can try 100 billion password guesses per second. Your 6-character password lasts about half a second.

buildup.text: Brute force attacks systematically try every possible combination. Dictionary attacks try common words and.

discovery.text: Modern GPUs can test billions of hashes per second. Password length matters exponentially more than complexity.

twist.text: Adding one character to a password multiplies cracking time by 95x. A 12-character password takes centuries.

climax.text: Brute force is math, not magic. Longer passwords win because each character multiplies the search space exponentially.

punchline.text: Six characters: half a second. Twelve: centuries.

quiz.question: Why does password length matter more than complexity?
options: Complex passwords are harder to remember
Each additional character multiplies the search space exponentially, greatly increasing cracking time
